Award.AwardTitle: Studies of Impurity-Atom Dynamics in Lattice-Modulated Bosonic Mixtures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The coupling of a particle to its surroundings enables important condensed-matter phenomena such as the formation of polarons in solid-state and low-temperature systems, and is a central concept in the study of decoherence and dissipation. This project focuses on the experimental study of such coupled systems using mixtures of ultracold bosonic atoms trapped in an optical lattice. Using a hyperfine-ground state mixture of bosonic atoms in state-dependent optical lattices allows for the immersion of localized atoms in a bosonic background medium. One of the goals of the projectis to detect polaronic energy shifts and clustering spectroscopically in the limit of strong interactions. Another goal is to study the dynamics of a localized, driven atomic spin coupled to a bosonic superfluid as a simple realization of a spin-boson model for the study of quantum dissipative effects. Using state-dependent potentials as a manipulation tool, a third goal is to study out-of-equilibrium dynamics of one-dimensional spin mixtures with the possibility of observing spin-charge separation.

The elucidation of behavior specific to complex materials will have the potential for broad scientific and technological impact that can ultimately benefit society. The project will advance the state of the art of quantum-gas research in this direction, and it will also provide scientific and technical training to both graduate and undergraduate students who will gain proficiency in the enabling technologies of lasers and optics, ultrahigh vacuum, and electronics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research carried out under this award was devoted to the dynamics of ultracold atoms in optical lattices, loaded from a Bose-Einstein condensate. Such optical lattice systems, which resemble the crystal lattices in solids controlling the motion of electrons, allow for fundamental and precise studies at the boundary between atomic physics, quantum optics, and condensed-matter physics.

In one set of experiments, we investigated the interplay between interactions and disorder. Upon application of a weak external force, atoms in a disorder-free lattice undergo oscillatory motion, which are known to damp out when interactions are present. However, we observed that in a disordered lattice, adding more interactions actually can mean less, rather than more, damping, due to a screening effect. Our findings are relevant for the description of condensed-matter systems ranging from superfluid helium in porous materials to superconductivity in granular or disordered materials.

In another set of experiments, we investigated the dynamics of a condensate that was coupled to an optical lattice, not originally seen by the condensate, using microwave radiation. The coupling resulted in the creation of a periodic array of holes in the condensate. When viewed as a matter-wave diffraction phenomenon, this constitutes a novel regime in which the diffracting object cannot be described by a potential. Our work sheds light on the notion of dressed states in atom optics and is of direct relevance for interferometry applications.

In a theoretical study, we investigated in detail the dynamics of atoms in an optical lattice that are coupled to an un-trapped state, using weak microwave radiation. We showed that, for realistic experimental conditions, this system can be used as a tunable model for dissipative phenomena. Our work sheds light on fundamental theoretical questions in quantum optics, and is of direct relevance for future experimental research on matter-wave decay, which is made possible through a newly developed magnetometry technique.
